choices.A: Enable ELB cross zone load balancing

questions.answer_description: Generally, AWS ELB routes each request to a zone with the minimum load. The Elastic Load Balancer provides a feature called sticky session which binds the user's session with a specific EC2 instance. If the sticky session is enabled the first request from the user will be redirected to any of the EC2 instances. But, henceforth, all requests from the same user will be redirected to the same EC2 instance. This ensures that all requests coming from the user during the session will be sent to the same application instance.

discussion.content:
C
When sticky session are enabled, if a request comes the first time from a (NEW) user to AWS ELB then the ELB routes each request to an EC2 instance in a zone with the minimum load, subsequent requests from the same user will be served by the same EC2 instance.

This is an odd question. ELB is already high available between multiple AZ in the same region. "A. R53" only makes sense if you have multiple ELB in various regions. I don't see any reference to that in the question.
This is why I think "C Auto Scaling" would be a preferred answer for this badly worded question..
ELB is a managed service guaranteed to work and be HA. So why does it need Rt 53 for this purpose?

Selected Answer: C
By combining Auto Scaling with ELB, the number of EC2 instances can be automatically adjusted as traffic increases or decreases, ensuring high availability (HA) and redundancy.
For example, new instances can be automatically added when the load is high, and unnecessary instances can be removed when the load is low, achieving cost optimization and increased availability.
